title: Book_Appeals_Process_.564
content: Tropicana Properties - VA Demo Course Tropicana Properties VA Demo Course VAdemoCourse Appeals Process This page is part of the content downloaded from Appeals Process on Thursday, 1 August 2024, 4:20 PM. Note that some content and any files larger than 400 MB are not downloaded.

title: Book_Appeals_Process_.564
content: Description ## Appeals Process for VA Benefits The appeals process for Veterans Affairs (VA) decisions regarding benefits is a multi-step procedure designed to ensure veterans have the opportunity to challenge and seek reconsideration of decisions they believe are incorrect or unfair. This comprehensive guide aims to demystify the process and provide veterans with the necessary tools and knowledge to effectively pursue their appeals.

title: Book_Appeals_Process_.564
content: ### Filing a Notice of Disagreement (NOD) The first critical step in the appeals process is filing a Notice of Disagreement (NOD). Veterans who disagree with a VA decision must submit VA Form 21-0958, known as the NOD, within one year from the date of the VA’s decision letter. This form is the veteran’s formal declaration that they are contesting the decision.

title: Book_Appeals_Process_.564
content: It is essential to clearly state the specific aspects of the decision that are being disputed and provide any new evidence or arguments to support the claim. Veterans should ensure all sections of the NOD are completed accurately to avoid delays in the processing of their appeal. ### Review Options: DRO vs. Board of Veterans' Appeals Upon filing the NOD, veterans have two primary options for review: 1.

title: Book_Appeals_Process_.564
content: **Decision Review Officer (DRO) Review**: This option allows for a de novo review of the case, meaning the DRO will re-examine all the evidence afresh, without giving any deference to the original decision. The DRO may hold an informal conference where the veteran or their representative can present additional evidence and clarify issues. This option can be beneficial for veterans seeking a quicker resolution than the traditional appeal route. 2.

title: Book_Appeals_Process_.564
content: **Traditional Appeal to the Board of Veterans' Appeals**: Alternatively, veterans can choose to have their case reviewed by the Board of Veterans' Appeals (BVA). The BVA offers a more formal process and may take longer but allows for a comprehensive review of the case. Veterans can submit additional evidence and request a hearing before a Veterans Law Judge (VLJ).

title: Book_Appeals_Process_.564
content: ### Hearings and Representation Veterans opting for a BVA review can choose between different types of hearings: - **Virtual Hearings**: Conducted via video conference, allowing veterans to participate from a convenient location. - **Travel Board Hearings**: Held at a regional VA office, where a VLJ travels to hear the case in person. - **Central Office Hearings**: Conducted in Washington, D.C., where the veteran appears before the VLJ at the BVA’s central office.

title: Book_Appeals_Process_.564
content: Preparation for these hearings is crucial. Veterans should gather and organize all relevant medical records, service documents, and any other supporting evidence. It is highly recommended to seek assistance from accredited representatives, such as Veterans Service Organizations (VSOs), attorneys, or claims agents who are well-versed in VA law and can provide valuable guidance and representation throughout the process.

title: Book_Appeals_Process_.564
content: ### Legal Assistance and Resources Veterans do not have to navigate the appeals process alone. Numerous resources are available to provide support and legal assistance: - **Veterans Service Organizations (VSOs)**: Organizations like the American Legion, Disabled American Veterans (DAV), and Veterans of Foreign Wars (VFW) offer free assistance to veterans in preparing and submitting their appeals.

title: Book_Appeals_Process_.564
content: - **Accredited Representatives**: These are individuals or organizations accredited by the VA to represent veterans. They can offer expert advice, help gather and submit evidence, and represent veterans at hearings. - **Legal Clinics and Pro Bono Services**: Many law schools and non-profit organizations offer free legal clinics or pro bono services specifically for veterans. ### Importance of Deadlines and Evidence Meeting deadlines is critical in the VA appeals process.

title: Book_Appeals_Process_.564
content: Failure to submit the NOD within the stipulated one-year period can result in the forfeiture of the right to appeal. Additionally, providing thorough and compelling evidence is essential to substantiate the appeal. Veterans should ensure all relevant documents, including medical records, service treatment records, and personal statements, are comprehensive and well-organized. ## VA Facilities Locator Accessing the appropriate healthcare facilities is vital for veterans' health and well-being.

title: Book_Appeals_Process_.564
content: The VA facilities locator is an invaluable tool that helps veterans find nearby VA hospitals, clinics, and community-based outpatient centers tailored to their healthcare needs. ### Using the VA Facilities Locator The VA facilities locator is an online tool accessible through the VA’s official website. Here’s how veterans can effectively use this tool: 1. **Search by Location**: Veterans can enter their city, state, or ZIP code to find the nearest VA facilities.

title: Book_Appeals_Process_.564
content: The locator provides a list of facilities within the specified area, along with their addresses and contact information. 2. **Filter by Services**: The tool allows users to filter search results based on the type of services needed, such as primary care, mental health services , specialty clinics, or emergency care. This helps veterans find the right facility that meets their specific healthcare requirements. 3.

title: Book_Appeals_Process_.564
content: **Access Facility Information**: Detailed information about each facility is available, including operating hours, available services, and directions. Veterans can also find contact details for scheduling appointments and seeking further assistance. ### Additional Support and Resources For veterans needing further assistance in accessing healthcare services , the document provides contact information for regional offices and patient advocates.

title: Book_Appeals_Process_.564
content: Patient advocates are available at most VA facilities to help veterans resolve issues with their care and navigate the VA healthcare system. Additionally, veterans can call the VA’s customer service line for help with using the locator tool or addressing other healthcare-related questions.

title: Book_Appeals_Process_.564
content: By offering comprehensive guidance on using the VA facilities locator, the document ensures that veterans have all the necessary information to access the benefits and services available to them, supporting their transition to civilian life and enhancing their overall well-being. This tool is a vital resource for ensuring veterans receive timely and appropriate medical care tailored to their needs.

title: Book_Disability_Compensation_.563
content: Tropicana Properties - VA Demo Course Tropicana Properties VA Demo Course VAdemoCourse Disability Compensation This page is part of the content downloaded from Disability Compensation on Thursday, 1 August 2024, 4:20 PM. Note that some content and any files larger than 400 MB are not downloaded.

title: Book_Disability_Compensation_.563
content: Description ### Eligibility for Disability Compensation Veterans who have sustained injuries or developed illnesses due to their service in the military may qualify for disability compensation from the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs (VA). To be eligible, the disability must be directly linked to the veteran's service, which is determined through evidence of the condition occurring or being exacerbated during active duty.

title: Book_Disability_Compensation_.563
content: This connection is crucial as it forms the basis of the veteran's entitlement to benefits. Service connection can be established through service medical records, private medical records, and statements from fellow service members or family members who can attest to the condition's onset or aggravation during military service. ### The VA Rating System The VA employs a comprehensive rating system to evaluate the severity of a veteran's disability and calculate the appropriate compensation.

title: Book_Disability_Compensation_.563
content: This system assigns a percentage rating from 0% to 100% in increments of 10%, reflecting the extent to which the disability impairs the veteran's ability to work and perform daily activities. A higher rating indicates a more severe disability and corresponds to higher monthly compensation payments.

title: Book_Disability_Compensation_.563
content: For instance, a veteran with a 10% disability rating receives a modest monthly benefit, while a veteran rated at 100%—indicative of total disability—is entitled to the maximum monthly benefit, which includes additional allowances for dependents. These ratings are based on the VA Schedule for Rating Disabilities (VASRD), which outlines specific criteria for evaluating different conditions.

title: Book_Disability_Compensation_.563
content: ### The Application Process Applying for disability compensation involves several key steps, starting with the submission of VA Form 21-526EZ, Application for Disability Compensation and Related Compensation Benefits. This form requires detailed information about the veteran's service, medical history, and the disabilities being claimed. Along with the form, veterans must provide supporting medical evidence, such as service treatment records, private medical records, and lay statements.

title: Book_Disability_Compensation_.563
content: In many cases, the VA will schedule a Compensation and Pension (C&P) exam, where a VA healthcare provider will assess the veteran’s condition and provide an evaluation that helps determine the appropriate disability rating. The entire process, from application submission to the final decision, can take several months, depending on the complexity of the claim and the availability of evidence.

title: Book_Disability_Compensation_.563
content: ### Types of Qualifying Disabilities Disabilities that qualify for compensation encompass a wide range of physical and mental health conditions. Common examples include post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), traumatic brain injury (TBI), hearing loss, chronic back pain, and conditions resulting from exposure to hazardous materials, such as Agent Orange or burn pits.

title: Book_Disability_Compensation_.563
content: The VA recognizes both direct service-connected disabilities, where the condition was directly caused by military service, and secondary service-connected disabilities, where a service-connected condition leads to or aggravates another disability. It is essential for veterans to provide comprehensive medical documentation and, if possible, seek statements from medical professionals linking the disability to their military service.

title: Book_Disability_Compensation_.563
content: ### Navigating the Evaluation and Appeal Process Once a claim is submitted, the VA will review the evidence, conduct any necessary examinations, and issue a rating decision. If a veteran disagrees with the rating decision, they have the right to appeal. The appeals process can be complex and involves several stages, including filing a Notice of Disagreement (NOD), requesting a review by a Decision Review Officer (DRO), and potentially taking the case to the Board of Veterans' Appeals (BVA).

title: Book_Disability_Compensation_.563
content: Veterans may seek assistance from accredited representatives, such as Veterans Service Organizations (VSOs), attorneys, or claims agents, who can provide guidance and representation throughout the process. ### Survivor Benefits Survivor benefits play a vital role in supporting the families of deceased veterans.

title: Book_Disability_Compensation_.563
content: Dependency and Indemnity Compensation (DIC) is a tax-free benefit paid to eligible survivors of service members who died while on active duty or as a result of a service-related injury or illness. Survivors' pension provides monthly payments to low-income surviving spouses and unmarried dependent children of deceased wartime veterans. These benefits help ensure financial stability for survivors who have lost their primary means of support.

title: Book_Disability_Compensation_.563
content: ### Burial Benefits The VA also offers burial benefits to honor the service of deceased veterans. These benefits include a gravesite in a VA national cemetery, a government headstone or marker, a burial flag, and a burial allowance to help cover the costs of burial and funeral expenses.

title: Book_Disability_Compensation_.563
content: The eligibility for these benefits typically requires that the veteran was discharged under conditions other than dishonorable and that the death occurred while the veteran was receiving or entitled to receive VA disability compensation or pension. ### Accessing Support Services In addition to financial benefits, the VA provides a range of counseling and support services to assist survivors during their time of need.

title: Book_Disability_Compensation_.563
content: This includes grief counseling, support groups, and access to mental health services . The VA also offers educational benefits for dependents, such as the Survivors’ and Dependents’ Educational Assistance (DEA) program, which provides financial aid for education and training. These services are designed to help survivors cope with their loss and rebuild their lives.

title: Book_Disability_Compensation_.563
content: In summary, disability compensation and survivor benefits are essential components of the VA's mission to support veterans and their families. By understanding the eligibility criteria, application process, and available resources, veterans and their loved ones can navigate the system more effectively and access the benefits they deserve. This file is part of the content downloaded from VA Demo Course by System Administrator on Thursday, 1 August 2024, 4:20 PM..

title: Book_Education_Benefits_.559
content: Tropicana Properties - VA Demo Course Tropicana Properties VA Demo Course VAdemoCourse Education Benefits This page is part of the content downloaded from Education Benefits on Thursday, 1 August 2024, 4:20 PM. Note that some content and any files larger than 400 MB are not downloaded.

title: Book_Education_Benefits_.559
content: Description The GI Bill offers a robust and multifaceted array of education benefits to veterans, aiming to facilitate their transition from military to civilian life through comprehensive support in education and training. These benefits encompass tuition, housing, and books, ensuring that veterans have the resources they need to pursue various educational and vocational pathways.

title: Book_Education_Benefits_.559
content: This support extends to undergraduate and graduate degrees, vocational training, and certification programs, providing veterans with the flexibility to tailor their education to their career goals. ### Post-9/11 GI Bill The Post-9/11 GI Bill stands out as one of the most substantial benefits available to veterans.

title: Book_Education_Benefits_.559
content: It provides up to 36 months of education benefits, which cover full tuition at public universities, a significant monthly housing allowance, and an annual stipend for books and supplies. For veterans attending private or foreign institutions, the bill covers tuition and fees up to a national maximum rate.

title: Book_Education_Benefits_.559
content: Additionally, veterans who choose to attend more expensive private schools or out-of-state public schools can benefit from the Yellow Ribbon Program, which helps cover costs that exceed the Post-9/11 GI Bill’s limits through partnerships between the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) and participating institutions. #### Specifics: - **Tuition and Fees**: Full coverage for in-state tuition at public institutions and up to $26,042.81 per academic year for private institutions as of 2024.

title: Book_Education_Benefits_.559
content: - **Monthly Housing Allowance (MHA)**: Based on the location of the school, the MHA is equivalent to the military Basic Allowance for Housing (BAH) for an E-5 with dependents. - **Books and Supplies Stipend**: Up to $1,000 per year, calculated at $41.67 per credit hour for up to 24 credit hours. - **Yellow Ribbon Program**: Additional funding provided by participating schools, matched by the VA, to cover tuition costs exceeding the Post-9/11 GI Bill cap.

title: Book_Education_Benefits_.559
content: ### Montgomery GI Bill The Montgomery GI Bill (MGIB) provides financial support for up to 36 months of education. Unlike the Post-9/11 GI Bill, the MGIB requires veterans to pay a monthly premium during their first year of service to be eligible for benefits. This bill caters to veterans pursuing degrees, certifications, and vocational training programs.

title: Book_Education_Benefits_.559
content: The MGIB-Active Duty (MGIB-AD) and MGIB-Selected Reserve (MGIB-SR) offer different levels of benefits depending on the veteran's service status, providing flexibility to those still serving in the reserve components. #### Specifics: - **Eligibility**: Requires a contribution of $1,200 during the first year of service. - **MGIB-Active Duty (MGIB-AD)**: Provides up to $2,150 per month for full-time students, with benefits available for ten years following discharge.

title: Book_Education_Benefits_.559
content: - **MGIB-Selected Reserve (MGIB-SR)**: Offers up to $439 per month for full-time students, available for 14 years from the eligibility date. - **Programs Covered**: Includes college degrees, vocational/technical training, flight training, apprenticeships/on-the-job training, and correspondence courses.

title: Book_Education_Benefits_.559
content: ### Yellow Ribbon Program The Yellow Ribbon Program enhances the Post-9/11 GI Bill by allowing institutions of higher learning to voluntarily enter agreements with the VA to fund tuition and fee expenses that exceed the highest public in-state undergraduate tuition rate. This program is particularly beneficial for veterans attending private institutions or graduate schools, which often have higher tuition rates.

title: Book_Education_Benefits_.559
content: Participating institutions can choose how much they will contribute, and the VA will match that amount, potentially covering a significant portion of the remaining tuition costs. #### Specifics: - **Institution Participation**: Not all institutions participate, and those that do set their own contribution amounts. - **Contribution Matching**: The VA matches the institution's contributions dollar-for-dollar, effectively doubling the support.

title: Book_Education_Benefits_.559
content: - **Application Process**: Veterans must be eligible for the Post-9/11 GI Bill at the 100% benefit level and apply through their school’s Yellow Ribbon Program liaison. ### Vocational Rehabilitation and Employment (VR&E) Program The VR&E program, also known as Chapter 31, is designed to help veterans with service-connected disabilities prepare for, find, and maintain suitable employment.

title: Book_Education_Benefits_.559
content: This program offers personalized services, including vocational counseling, training, education, and job placement assistance. VR&E services are tailored to meet the unique needs of each veteran, focusing on maximizing their independence in daily living and ensuring long-term career success. This program also provides support for self-employment and independent living services, addressing the broad spectrum of challenges faced by disabled veterans.

title: Book_Education_Benefits_.559
content: #### Specifics: - **Eligibility**: Veterans with a service-connected disability rating of at least 20%, or 10% with a serious employment handicap. - **Services Provided**: Career counseling, job training, resume development, and job placement assistance. - **Independent Living Services**: For veterans who are severely disabled and unable to work, these services help improve their ability to live as independently as possible.

title: Book_Education_Benefits_.559
content: - **Duration and Benefits**: Typically up to 48 months of education and training benefits, with possible extensions based on individual circumstances. ### Eligibility Criteria and Application Process Eligibility for these education benefits varies by program but generally requires an honorable discharge and fulfillment of specific service requirements.

title: Book_Education_Benefits_.559
content: For example, the Post-9/11 GI Bill requires at least 90 days of aggregate service after September 10, 2001, or 30 continuous days if discharged due to a service-connected disability. The application process is streamlined through the VA's website, where veterans can submit applications for educational benefits, manage their education plan, and track their remaining benefits.

title: Book_Education_Benefits_.559
content: The VA also offers an Education and Career Counseling program (Chapter 36) to provide personalized guidance on career paths and educational opportunities, ensuring veterans make informed decisions about their future. #### Specifics: - **Post-9/11 GI Bill**: Requires service of at least 90 days after September 10, 2001, or 30 continuous days if discharged for a service-connected disability.

title: Book_Education_Benefits_.559
content: - **Montgomery GI Bill**: Requires completion of high school or an equivalency certificate and a contribution to the program during the first year of service. - **Application Process**: Applications can be submitted online through the VA’s eBenefits portal, where veterans can also check the status of their benefits.

title: Book_Education_Benefits_.559
content: - **Education and Career Counseling (Chapter 36)**: Available to veterans and service members within six months of discharge or up to one year post-discharge, providing career guidance and support. ### Additional Support and Resources Beyond direct financial benefits, the GI Bill and associated programs offer a wide range of support services. These include academic and career counseling, tutoring assistance, and support for licensing and certification tests.

title: Book_Education_Benefits_.559
content: Veterans can also transfer their Post-9/11 GI Bill benefits to a spouse or children, providing educational opportunities for their dependents. The VA continuously updates and expands these programs to address the evolving needs of veterans, ensuring they receive the support necessary to succeed in their post-military lives.

title: Book_Education_Benefits_.559
content: #### Specifics: - **Transfer of Benefits**: Eligible service members can transfer unused Post-9/11 GI Bill benefits to their spouse or children, with the requirement to serve an additional four years. - **Academic Support**: Tutoring assistance is available, with the VA reimbursing up to $100 per month for tutorial services, up to a maximum of $1,200. - **Certification and Licensing**: The VA covers the cost of certification and licensing tests, reimbursing up to $2,000 per test.

title: Book_Education_Benefits_.559
content: - **VetSuccess on Campus (VSOC)**: Provides on-campus support and resources to veterans, helping them navigate academic and career services. - **Student Veterans of America (SVA)**: A network of student veteran groups on college campuses that provide peer support and advocacy. In conclusion, the GI Bill and its associated programs represent a comprehensive commitment to supporting veterans in their educational and career endeavors.

title: Book_Education_Benefits_.559
content: By providing extensive financial support and tailored services, these programs help veterans achieve their academic goals, gain valuable skills, and successfully transition to civilian careers. The ongoing evolution of these benefits reflects the nation's dedication to honoring the service and sacrifice of its veterans by investing in their future success. This file is part of the content downloaded from VA Demo Course by System Administrator on Thursday, 1 August 2024, 4:20 PM..

title: Book_Employment_and_Training_..._.562
content: Tropicana Properties - VA Demo Course Tropicana Properties VA Demo Course VAdemoCourse Employment and Training Programs This page is part of the content downloaded from Employment and Training Programs on Thursday, 1 August 2024, 4:20 PM. Note that some content and any files larger than 400 MB are not downloaded.

title: Book_Employment_and_Training_..._.562
content: Description Veterans seeking to transition from military service to civilian employment have access to a diverse range of employment and training programs designed to support their unique needs and experiences. These programs aim to leverage the skills and discipline veterans acquired during their service while providing new competencies necessary for success in civilian careers.

title: Book_Employment_and_Training_..._.562
content: Among the various resources available, resume workshops, job fairs, and vocational training are particularly noteworthy for their tailored approach to veteran employment. ### Resume Workshops and Job Fairs Resume workshops are a crucial component of many veteran employment programs. These workshops focus on translating military skills and experience into language that civilian employers can understand and value.

title: Book_Employment_and_Training_..._.562
content: Veterans learn how to highlight their leadership, problem-solving abilities, and technical skills in a way that aligns with job market demands. Additionally, job fairs specifically targeted at veterans offer direct access to employers who are eager to hire from this talent pool. These events often feature recruiters from a wide range of industries, providing veterans with the opportunity to explore different career paths and network with potential employers.

title: Book_Employment_and_Training_..._.562
content: ### Vocational Training Programs Vocational training programs are designed to equip veterans with new skills that are in demand in the civilian workforce. These programs cover a broad spectrum of trades and professions, from information technology and cybersecurity to healthcare and advanced manufacturing.

title: Book_Employment_and_Training_..._.562
content: For instance, programs like the Veterans Affairs (VA) Vocational Rehabilitation and Employment (VR&E) services offer personalized training plans that cater to veterans with service-connected disabilities. The aim is to ensure that every veteran, regardless of their physical or mental health status, has the opportunity to pursue a fulfilling career. ### Transition Assistance Program (TAP) The Transition Assistance Program (TAP) is a cornerstone of the support system for transitioning veterans.

title: Book_Employment_and_Training_..._.562
content: TAP offers a comprehensive suite of services including workshops on resume writing, job searching, and interviewing skills. These workshops are designed to demystify the job application process and give veterans the tools they need to compete in the civilian job market. Additionally, TAP provides valuable information on veterans' benefits, helping participants understand and maximize the support available to them.

title: Book_Employment_and_Training_..._.562
content: ### Veterans Employment Center The Veterans Employment Center (VEC) serves as a one-stop online resource for veterans seeking employment. The VEC offers a robust job search engine, career advice, and a resume builder tailored specifically to veterans. This platform connects veterans with employers who have committed to hiring from this demographic, ensuring that veterans have access to job opportunities that recognize and value their service.

title: Book_Employment_and_Training_..._.562
content: The VEC also provides information on upcoming job fairs and hiring events, further facilitating direct connections between veterans and potential employers. ### Private Sector Partnerships Partnerships between the VA and private sector employers play a significant role in expanding employment opportunities for veterans. These collaborations often involve specialized training programs and hiring initiatives that prioritize veteran applicants.

title: Book_Employment_and_Training_..._.562
content: For example, many companies participate in the VA’s Veteran Employment Through Technology Education Courses (VET TEC) program, which offers high-tech training to veterans in fields like software development, information technology, and data processing. By aligning their hiring practices with veteran-friendly policies, these companies help bridge the gap between military service and civilian employment.

title: Book_Employment_and_Training_..._.562
content: ### Eligibility and Support Services Eligibility for veteran employment and training programs typically requires proof of veteran status, which can be obtained through documents such as a DD-214 form. Veterans can apply for these programs online or through local VA offices. In addition to training and employment services, veterans can also access career counseling and job placement assistance.

title: Book_Employment_and_Training_..._.562
content: These support services are crucial for helping veterans navigate the often complex transition from military to civilian life, providing guidance and resources tailored to their specific needs. In conclusion, the array of employment and training programs available to veterans is designed to facilitate a smooth and successful transition to civilian careers.

title: Book_Employment_and_Training_..._.562
content: By offering targeted resources such as resume workshops, vocational training, and comprehensive support services through programs like TAP and the Veterans Employment Center, these initiatives ensure that veterans are well-prepared to enter and thrive in the civilian job market. Partnerships with private sector employers further enhance these efforts, creating a supportive network that recognizes and values the contributions of veterans.

title: Book_Employment_and_Training_..._.562
content: This file is part of the content downloaded from VA Demo Course by System Administrator on Thursday, 1 August 2024, 4:20 PM..

title: Book_Housing_Assistance_.560
content: Tropicana Properties - VA Demo Course Tropicana Properties VA Demo Course VAdemoCourse Housing Assistance This page is part of the content downloaded from Housing Assistance on Thursday, 1 August 2024, 4:20 PM. Note that some content and any files larger than 400 MB are not downloaded. Description Veterans can access a variety of housing assistance programs designed to help them secure stable and affordable housing.

title: Book_Housing_Assistance_.560
content: These programs are tailored to address different needs, from purchasing a home to modifying existing residences for disabilities and providing support for homeless veterans. Understanding the range of available programs and their specific benefits can help veterans make informed decisions about their housing options. ### VA Home Loans VA home loans are a cornerstone of veteran housing assistance, offering several advantages over conventional loans. These loans are backed by the U.S.

title: Book_Housing_Assistance_.560
content: Department of Veterans Affairs, which guarantees a portion of the loan, thereby reducing the risk for lenders and enabling them to offer favorable terms to veterans. One of the most significant benefits of VA home loans is the competitive interest rates, which are often lower than those of traditional loans. Additionally, VA loans typically require no down payment, making homeownership more accessible, especially for veterans who may not have substantial savings.

title: Book_Housing_Assistance_.560
content: Another key advantage is the absence of private mortgage insurance (PMI), which is usually required for conventional loans with down payments of less than 20%. This can save veterans hundreds of dollars per month. Furthermore, VA loans are reusable, allowing veterans to use their benefits multiple times throughout their lives, provided they meet the eligibility criteria each time.

title: Book_Housing_Assistance_.560
content: ### Adaptive Housing Grants For veterans with service-connected disabilities, adaptive housing grants provide essential support to modify homes and ensure they are accessible and functional. The Specially Adapted Housing (SAH) grant is designed for veterans with severe service-connected disabilities, such as the loss or loss of use of both legs, blindness in both eyes, or certain severe burns.

title: Book_Housing_Assistance_.560
content: This grant helps veterans purchase, build, or modify a home to meet their adaptive needs, with a maximum allowable grant amount that is adjusted annually. In 2024, for example, the maximum SAH grant amount is $109,986. The Special Housing Adaptation (SHA) grant, on the other hand, is aimed at veterans with less severe but still significant disabilities, such as the loss or loss of use of both hands or certain respiratory or neurological conditions.

title: Book_Housing_Assistance_.560
content: The SHA grant provides financial assistance for similar purposes as the SAH grant but typically with a lower maximum grant amount. ### Homelessness Assistance Programs For veterans facing homelessness, the VA offers a comprehensive array of programs designed to provide temporary housing and support services. The Homeless Providers Grant and Per Diem (GPD) Program funds community agencies that provide services to homeless veterans.

title: Book_Housing_Assistance_.560
content: These grants support transitional housing and offer services such as job training, health care, and counseling to help veterans reintegrate into the community. The Supportive Services for Veteran Families (SSVF) program is another critical initiative that aims to prevent veteran homelessness and rapidly rehouse those who have become homeless. SSVF provides case management and supportive services to help veterans and their families obtain and maintain stable housing.

title: Book_Housing_Assistance_.560
content: This can include assistance with rent, utilities, moving costs, and other housing-related expenses. The program operates on a housing first model, which prioritizes placing homeless veterans into permanent housing as quickly as possible, followed by supportive services to ensure long-term stability. ### Application Process and Eligibility The application process for these programs typically involves submitting specific forms and required documentation.

title: Book_Housing_Assistance_.560
content: For VA home loans, veterans need to complete VA Form 26-1880, Request for a Certificate of Eligibility, which verifies their service history and eligibility for the loan benefit. Documentation required for this form can include discharge or separation papers (such as a DD-214) and records of service.

title: Book_Housing_Assistance_.560
content: Eligibility criteria for VA home loans generally include minimum service requirements, such as 90 consecutive days of active service during wartime or 181 days during peacetime, or six years in the National Guard or Reserves. For adaptive housing grants, veterans must provide evidence of their service-connected disabilities, typically through a rating decision from the VA.

title: Book_Housing_Assistance_.560
content: The application forms, such as VA Form 26-4555 for the SAH and SHA grants, require detailed information about the veteran's disability and housing needs. Homelessness assistance programs often involve working with VA social workers or community-based organizations to assess the veteran's situation and determine the best course of action.

title: Book_Housing_Assistance_.560
content: Veterans may need to provide documentation of their military service, proof of homelessness or risk of homelessness, and other personal information to access these services. ### Conclusion The array of housing assistance programs available to veterans reflects a commitment to addressing the diverse housing needs of those who have served in the military.

title: Book_Housing_Assistance_.560
content: From facilitating homeownership through VA loans to supporting veterans with disabilities through adaptive housing grants and providing crucial services to prevent and address homelessness, these programs play a vital role in ensuring veterans have access to stable, affordable, and suitable housing. Understanding the specifics of each program, including the benefits, eligibility requirements, and application processes, empowers veterans to take full advantage of the support available to them.

title: Book_Housing_Assistance_.560

title: Book_Mental_Health_Services_.561
content: Tropicana Properties - VA Demo Course Tropicana Properties VA Demo Course VAdemoCourse Mental Health Services This page is part of the content downloaded from Mental Health Services on Thursday, 1 August 2024, 4:20 PM. Note that some content and any files larger than 400 MB are not downloaded. Description The Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) offers a comprehensive range of mental health services tailored to meet the unique needs of veterans.

title: Book_Mental_Health_Services_.561
content: These services encompass various forms of counseling, therapy, and support groups, all designed to address conditions such as post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), depression, anxiety, and other mental health issues that veterans may experience due to their military service. The VA's mental health programs aim to provide veterans with the tools and support necessary to manage their mental health and improve their overall quality of life.

title: Book_Mental_Health_Services_.561
content: ### Counseling and Therapy Options The VA provides a diverse array of counseling and therapy options to accommodate the different preferences and needs of veterans. These options include: - **Individual Counseling**: This one-on-one therapy is tailored to address the specific issues a veteran may be facing. Therapists use various techniques to help veterans process their experiences and develop coping strategies.

title: Book_Mental_Health_Services_.561
content: - **Group Counseling**: Group sessions allow veterans to connect with peers who have similar experiences. This setting can foster a sense of camaraderie and mutual support, which is particularly beneficial for those who may feel isolated. - **Family Counseling**: Military service can significantly impact families, and the VA offers family counseling to help veterans and their loved ones navigate these challenges together.

title: Book_Mental_Health_Services_.561
content: This type of therapy aims to improve communication and strengthen relationships. - **Specialized Therapies**: The VA employs evidence-based therapies such as cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) and prolonged exposure therapy (PE). CBT helps veterans reframe negative thought patterns, while PE focuses on reducing the power of trauma-related memories through controlled exposure. ### Support Groups Support groups are a vital component of the VA’s mental health services.

title: Book_Mental_Health_Services_.561
content: These groups provide a safe and supportive environment where veterans can share their experiences and learn from others who have faced similar challenges. Support groups can be particularly effective for dealing with conditions like PTSD and depression, as they reduce feelings of isolation and provide practical advice and encouragement from peers.

title: Book_Mental_Health_Services_.561
content: ### Specialized Programs The VA has developed several specialized programs to address the unique needs of veterans: - **Veterans Crisis Line**: This is a confidential, 24/7 service that offers immediate assistance to veterans in crisis. Veterans can reach out via phone, text, or online chat to speak with trained professionals who can provide support and resources. - **Vet Centers**: These community-based centers offer a range of counseling and outreach services.

title: Book_Mental_Health_Services_.561
content: Vet Centers provide readjustment counseling to help veterans transition back to civilian life, bereavement counseling for those dealing with the loss of a loved one, and military sexual trauma (MST) counseling for survivors of MST. These centers are designed to be more accessible and less formal than traditional VA medical centers, making them an appealing option for many veterans.

title: Book_Mental_Health_Services_.561
content: ### Accessing Services Accessing VA mental health services typically involves contacting a local VA medical center or Vet Center. Veterans can schedule appointments for ongoing support, which might include regular individual or group therapy sessions. The Veterans Crisis Line provides an immediate avenue for support in times of crisis, ensuring that help is available whenever it is needed.

title: Book_Mental_Health_Services_.561
content: Additionally, the VA offers various online resources and telehealth options, making mental health services more accessible to veterans regardless of their location. ### Ongoing Support and Resources The VA is committed to providing ongoing support to veterans through continuous counseling sessions, group therapy, and access to a wealth of mental health resources. This includes educational materials, self-help tools, and community programs designed to promote mental wellness.

title: Book_Mental_Health_Services_.561
content: The VA also collaborates with other organizations to expand the reach and effectiveness of its mental health services. In conclusion, the VA's comprehensive mental health services are designed to meet the diverse needs of veterans, helping them manage the unique challenges they face due to their service.

title: Book_Mental_Health_Services_.561
content: Through a combination of individual and group counseling, specialized therapies, and community-based support programs, the VA strives to improve the mental health and overall well-being of veterans across the country. This file is part of the content downloaded from VA Demo Course by System Administrator on Thursday, 1 August 2024, 4:20 PM..

The most critical portions of this questionnaire are the following: §  Does the veteran highlight in the
summary the actual stressor or stressors that occurred to them with great
detail, having the following: ·       Time- Time must be within two months
of the event and stressor information. ·       Place/Area- General location (Laos,
Baghdad, Ft. Bliss Barracks Bldg. 5-Room 235, etc.) ·       Unit ·       Names- Having names is the most critical
aspect of this section.

title: Book_MST_Checklist_.566
content:
·       What occurred, to the best of my
recollection? §  If the veteran speaks about any other
condition, this is OK since the veteran must now explain how the veteran’s MST
is affecting them. §  The Chronic Pain and Mental Health
Checklist impacts the overall possible rating the Veteran might receive
(please refer to the VA Mental Health Rating Table). §  The Depression Inventory does have
weight but is not a complete disqualification.

title: Book_MST_Checklist_.566
content:
Always remember to tell the
veteran to be Brutally Honest with all his
answers. q Track the progress of the Veteran. q Follow up on all questionnaires sent. q Once the questionnaire is received,
check for accuracy regarding physical address and other personally identifiable
Information. q If the Questionnaire is GTG, call the
Veteran and tell him we are ready to begin filing for MST. q Review the reason and ensure the veteran
understands the strategy.

title: Book_MST_Checklist_.566
content:
q Once the veterans confirm the
strategy, annotate on the note section “Veteran agrees
with Strategy - Date-Time. ” q Send Veteran to Proposed Strategy This file is part of the content downloaded from VA Demo Course by System Administrator on Thursday, 1 August 2024, 4:20 PM..

Conditions Veterans Benefits from the State of Texas Veteran Services > VA Benefit Programs > Veterans Benefits from the State of Texas State of Texas Benefit Programs for Veterans There are a number of State of Texas benefit programs to which veterans may be entitled.

title: https://www.tarrantcountytx.gov/en/veteran-services/va-benefit-programs/veterans-benefits-from-the-state-of-texas.html
content: The following is a brief description of the primary programs. Contact the Tarrant County Veteran Services Office at 817-531-5645 if you have any questions. Property Tax Exemption Disabled veterans who meet certain requirements, their surviving spouses and the spouses and minor children of a person who dies on active duty in the U. S. Armed Forces are eligible for property tax exemptions on the appraised value of their property.

title: https://www.tarrantcountytx.gov/en/veteran-services/va-benefit-programs/veterans-benefits-from-the-state-of-texas.html
content: The exemption is mandatory and applies to taxes levied by all taxing authorities in the state. A veteran, whose service-connected disabilities are rated less than 10 percent by the Department of Veteran Affairs (DVA), or a branch of the Armed Forces, is not entitled to property tax exemption. You will need a letter from the Department of Veteran Affairs showing your current disability rating. Contact the DVA at 800-827-1000 to get this letter.

title: https://www.tarrantcountytx.gov/en/veteran-services/va-benefit-programs/veterans-benefits-from-the-state-of-texas.html
content: The appraisal district will not take your DVA award letter. You will also need your discharge document. Contact the Tarrant Appraisal District at 817-284-0024 for more information also view the Tarrant Appraisal District website .

title: https://www.tarrantcountytx.gov/en/veteran-services/va-benefit-programs/veterans-benefits-from-the-state-of-texas.html
content: Disabled Veterans License Plates and Parking Placards You may apply for Disabled Veteran license plates for your car, light truck or motorcycle if you are certified by the Department of Veteran Affairs to have a 50 percent or higher service-related disability, or at least 40 percent due to amputation of a lower extremity. An annual $3 fee is collected for the first set of plates but no regular registration fee.

title: https://www.tarrantcountytx.gov/en/veteran-services/va-benefit-programs/veterans-benefits-from-the-state-of-texas.html
content: You may receive an additional set of plates, but you are required to pay the regular registration fee and other applicable fees. Persons entitled to license plates for disabled veterans may also elect to receive a standard license plate at the same cost in lieu of the first set of disabled veteran plates. You will need a letter from the Department of Veteran Affairs showing your current disability rating. Contact the DVA at 800-827-1000 to get this letter.

title: https://www.tarrantcountytx.gov/en/veteran-services/va-benefit-programs/veterans-benefits-from-the-state-of-texas.html
content: You will also need your discharge document. Contact the vehicle registration office for more details at 817-884-1100. Parking Privileges for Certain Veterans When a vehicle with disabled veteran plates is being operated by or for the disabled veteran, the disabled veteran may use any parking space or area that is designated specifically for persons with physical disabilities.

title: https://www.tarrantcountytx.gov/en/veteran-services/va-benefit-programs/veterans-benefits-from-the-state-of-texas.html
content: Vehicles that display Disabled Veteran, the Air Force Cross, the Distinguished Service Cross, the Army Distinguished Service Cross, the Navy Cross, Pearl Harbor Survivor, Purple Heart, Prisoner of War or Congressional Medal of Honor license plates may park free of charge at a parking meter operated by a governmental authority other than the federal government. The vehicle must be driven by or for the transportation of the person who registered the vehicle.

title: https://www.tarrantcountytx.gov/en/veteran-services/va-benefit-programs/veterans-benefits-from-the-state-of-texas.html
content: Other fees for parking garages and lots are governed by local governments who have the option of passing ordinances for the exemption of fees for a disabled veteran. Contact the vehicle registration office for more details at 817-884-1100. Application forms can be obtained by calling the Texas Department of Transportation at 512-374-5010 or by visiting www.dot.state.tx.us . In addition, veterans may park at the DFW airport free of charge.

title: https://www.tarrantcountytx.gov/en/veteran-services/va-benefit-programs/veterans-benefits-from-the-state-of-texas.html
content: Specialty License Plates Disabled Veteran, Former Prisoner of War, Pearl Harbor Survivor, Purple Heart and Medal of Honor plates are among the special license plates available for personal use on an automobile or light commercial vehicle of one ton or less. Disabled Veterans must have a service-connected disability rating of 50 percent or more, or at least 40 percent due to amputation of a lower extremity.

title: https://www.tarrantcountytx.gov/en/veteran-services/va-benefit-programs/veterans-benefits-from-the-state-of-texas.html
content: Former military and civilian prisoners of war are eligible if they were captured or incarcerated by an enemy of the U. S. during a period of conflict with the U. S. and were U. S. citizens at the time of capture. You will need a letter from the Department of Veteran Affairs showing your current disability rating. Contact the DVA at 800-827-1000 to get this letter. You will also need your discharge document. Contact the vehicle registration office for more details at 817-884-1100.

title: https://www.tarrantcountytx.gov/en/veteran-services/va-benefit-programs/veterans-benefits-from-the-state-of-texas.html
content: For fee schedule and applications, visit www.dot.state.tx.us or call the Texas Department of Transportation office at 512-374-5010. Free Drivers License for Disabled Veterans Texas drivers licenses may be furnished free of charge to veterans who have service-connected disabilities rated at 60 percent or more by the Department of Veteran Affairs or by a branch of the U. S. Armed Forces. Application must be made prior to the time the present driver's license expires.

title: https://www.tarrantcountytx.gov/en/veteran-services/va-benefit-programs/veterans-benefits-from-the-state-of-texas.html
content: Application forms may be obtained from the Department of Public Safety's (DPS) license examining offices located throughout the state. Proof of the veteran's disability rating must accompany the application. Contact the DVA at 1-800-827-1000 to get a letter showing your current disability rating. Contact the DPS Drivers License Office in Fort Worth at 817-294-1075, 6413 Woodway Drive, Ft Worth, TX 76133, for more information.

title: https://www.tarrantcountytx.gov/en/veteran-services/va-benefit-programs/veterans-benefits-from-the-state-of-texas.html
content: Veteran Designation for State of Texas Driver's Licenses for Disabled Veterans The Texas Department of Public Safety now offers a veteran designation on the face of driver licenses for qualifying veterans. Veterans must visit a driver license office and present an original military discharge document or VA letter showing that they received an honorable discharge or a general discharge under honorable conditions in order to be eligible for the veteran designation.

title: https://www.tarrantcountytx.gov/en/veteran-services/va-benefit-programs/veterans-benefits-from-the-state-of-texas.html
content: Contact the Texas Department of Public Safety at 512-424-2600 or by visiting the Texas Department of Public Safety website. Veterans Employment Services The Texas Veterans Commission offers employment services to Texas veterans and helps employers find qualified veteran job applicants. Employment representatives offer one-on-one assistance to veterans with job applications and resume preparation, plus job matching and searches.

title: https://www.tarrantcountytx.gov/en/veteran-services/va-benefit-programs/veterans-benefits-from-the-state-of-texas.html
content: Additional intensive services are provided to disabled veterans and veterans with other barriers to employment -- especially homeless veterans. Go to TVC website to find the employment representatives near you. In Fort Worth, there are representatives at the Resource Connection at 817-804-4235, on E. Lancaster at 817-413-2891, and N. Main at 817-804-2664.

title: https://www.tarrantcountytx.gov/en/veteran-services/va-benefit-programs/veterans-benefits-from-the-state-of-texas.html
content: Veteran's Preference and Military Service Credit (for State of Texas employment) Veterans have preference in employment with State agencies or offices, as do widows/widowers and children of those killed on active duty. State agencies must practice veterans' preference until they have reached 40 percent employment.

title: https://www.tarrantcountytx.gov/en/veteran-services/va-benefit-programs/veterans-benefits-from-the-state-of-texas.html
content: Non-retiree veterans who are employed by the State of Texas are entitled to claim their active-duty military time toward retirement, provided they present a proper request and pay to the Employee Retirement System the specified amount of retirement contribution for the time spent in the military. All veterans may also use their military time toward retirement if they are members of the State Teachers Retirement System. Contact the Texas Veterans Commission at 512-463-5538 for more information.

title: https://www.tarrantcountytx.gov/en/veteran-services/va-benefit-programs/veterans-benefits-from-the-state-of-texas.html
content: Home, Land and Home Improvement Loans for Texas Veterans The Texas Veterans Land Board administers three veterans' loan programs:  The Land Loan Program, Veterans Housing Loan Program, and the Veterans Home Improvement Loan Program. These programs are especially advantageous for disabled veterans. Contact the Texas Veterans Land Board at 800-252-8387 for more information.

title: https://www.tarrantcountytx.gov/en/veteran-services/va-benefit-programs/veterans-benefits-from-the-state-of-texas.html
content: Texas Veterans Cemeteries The Texas State Cemetery Program provides state-managed perpetual shrines for veterans near family and friends. Currently, the Texas Veterans Land Board operates 4 cemeteries:  the Central Texas State Veterans Cemetery in Killeen; the Rio Grande Valley State Veterans Cemetery in Mission; the Texas State Veterans Cemetery in Abilene; and the Coastal Bend State Cemetery in Corpus Christi.

title: https://www.tarrantcountytx.gov/en/veteran-services/va-benefit-programs/veterans-benefits-from-the-state-of-texas.html
content: Further information can be obtained by calling the Texas Veterans Land Board at 800-252-8387. Texas State Veterans Homes The Texas State Veterans Homes Program offers affordable, long-term nursing care to Texas veterans, their spouses and Gold Star Parents. The homes are located in Amarillo, Big Spring, Bonham, El Paso, Floresville, McAllen, Temple and Tyler.

title: https://www.tarrantcountytx.gov/en/veteran-services/va-benefit-programs/veterans-benefits-from-the-state-of-texas.html
content: Further information can be obtained by calling the Texas Veterans Land Board at 800-252-8387 or visiting the Texas Veterans Land Board website . Hazelwood Act Educational Benefits The Texas Hazelwood Act is an education benefit providing eligible veterans up to 150 credit hours of tuition exemption at a state-supported college or university.

title: https://www.tarrantcountytx.gov/en/veteran-services/va-benefit-programs/veterans-benefits-from-the-state-of-texas.html
content: To be eligible, a veteran must (1) have been a Texas resident upon entry into the military, entered into active federal duty in the State of Texas, or declared Texas as his or her home of record at the time of entry into the armed forces as documented on his or her military discharge document; (2) have a military discharge of honorable or general, under honorable conditions; and (3) not be in default on a federal education loan or student loan made or guaranteed by the State of Texas.

title: https://www.tarrantcountytx.gov/en/veteran-services/va-benefit-programs/veterans-benefits-from-the-state-of-texas.html
content: For more information about eligibility for the Hazelwood Act go to website or call the Texas Veterans Commission at 512-463-5538. Free Recording of Discharges Under Local Government Code, Sec.192.002, the county clerk in each county is required to record, free of charge, the official discharge of a veteran who served in the U. S. Armed Forces.

title: https://www.tarrantcountytx.gov/en/veteran-services/va-benefit-programs/veterans-benefits-from-the-state-of-texas.html
content: The veteran must take his or her discharge document to the county clerk to have it filed, at which point the discharge document will become a confidential record for 75 years from the file date. This free service is very important as it provides veterans with a ready source from which they can obtain a certified copy of their discharge whenever it is needed. Contact the Tarrant County Clerk's office at 817-884-1550 for this service.

title: https://www.tarrantcountytx.gov/en/veteran-services/va-benefit-programs/veterans-benefits-from-the-state-of-texas.html
content: No Cost Medical Records Under the Health and Safety Code, Chapter 161, Subchapter M, medical records or mental health records, Texas veterans are eligible for no cost medical records when they are obtained to file a claim for disability against the Department of Veteran Affairs. The health care provider or health care facility is not required to provide more than one complete record for the patient or former patient without charge.

title: https://www.tarrantcountytx.gov/en/veteran-services/va-benefit-programs/veterans-benefits-from-the-state-of-texas.html
content: Also, it should be noted, that some medical facilities may charge a small administrative fee for obtaining the records. Go to www.statutes.legis.state.tx.us/docs/HS/htm/HS.161.htm to get a copy of the code to give to health care providers. Fishing and Hunting Licenses A disabled veteran who has a service-connected disability rating of 60 percent or higher, or has the loss of use of a lower extremity, can receive hunting and fishing licenses at a reduced cost.

title: https://www.tarrantcountytx.gov/en/veteran-services/va-benefit-programs/veterans-benefits-from-the-state-of-texas.html
content: Reduced cost hunting and fishing licenses can be obtained anywhere such licenses are sold. The veteran must provide proof of the service-connected disability rating at the time of purchase of the license. Call the VA at 800-827-1000 to get a disability rating letter. Contact the Texas Parks and Wildlife Department at 800-792-1112 or visit them at Texas Parks and Wildlife website for more information.

title: https://www.tarrantcountytx.gov/en/veteran-services/va-benefit-programs/veterans-benefits-from-the-state-of-texas.html
content: Concealed Handgun License Fees Concealed handgun license fees for the issuance of an original, duplicate, modified or renewed license is waived for members of the U. S. Armed Forces, including a member of the reserves, national guard or state guard. Fees are also waived for a veteran who, within 365 days preceding the date of application, was honorably discharged from the branch of service in which the person served.

title: https://www.tarrantcountytx.gov/en/veteran-services/va-benefit-programs/veterans-benefits-from-the-state-of-texas.html
content: Fees are reduced by 50 percent for a veteran who, was honorably discharged from the branch of service in which the person served. Call the VA at 800-827-1000 to get a disability rating letter. Contact the Texas Department of Public Safety at 512-424-7293 for more information.

title: https://www.tarrantcountytx.gov/en/veteran-services/va-benefit-programs/veterans-benefits-from-the-state-of-texas.html
content: State Park Admission The State Parklands Passport provides free admission to Texas State parks for any veteran who has a service-connected disability rating of 60 percent or higher, or a service-connected disability that resulted in the loss of use of a lower extremity. Application for the State Parklands Passport can be made at the headquarters office of any Texas State Park by providing evidence of the service-connected disability rating.

title: https://www.tarrantcountytx.gov/en/veteran-services/va-benefit-programs/veterans-benefits-from-the-state-of-texas.html
content: The State Parklands Passport is available to any veteran who meets the requirements, whether or not the veteran resides in Texas. Veterans will only receive free admission to state parks; the passport does not exempt veterans from payment of other charges, such as camping fees. Call the VA at 800-827-1000 to get a disability rating letter. For more information, contact the Texas Parks and Wildlife Department at 800-792-1112.

title: https://www.tarrantcountytx.gov/en/veteran-services/va-benefit-programs/veterans-benefits-from-the-state-of-texas.html
content: Contract Preferences All state agencies, when purchasing goods, including agricultural goods, shall give preference to goods produced or offered by a Texas bidder. A Texas bidder that is owned by a service-disabled veteran who is a Texas resident shall be given first preference and goods produced in this state or offered by other Texas bidders shall be given second preference, if the cost to the state and quality are equal.

title: https://www.tarrantcountytx.gov/en/veteran-services/va-benefit-programs/veterans-benefits-from-the-state-of-texas.html
content: Contact the Texas Veterans Commission at 877-898-3833 for more information. This page was last modified on September 13, 2023 TARRANT COUNTY, TEXAS County Telephone Operator 817-884-1111 Tarrant County provides the information contained in this web site as a public service. Every effort is made to ensure that information provided is correct. However, in any case where legal reliance on information contained in these pages is required, the official records of Tarrant County should be consulted.

eBenefits More Benefits Veteran State Benefits Texas State Veteran Benefits Military.com | By Jim Absher Published January 07, 2022 The state of Texas provides several veteran benefits.

title: https://www.military.com/benefits/veteran-state-benefits/texas-state-veterans-benefits.html
content: See which state benefits are available. Texas Veterans Homes Texas has nine veterans homes in Amarillo, Big Spring, Bonham, El Paso, Floresville, Houston, McAllen, Temple and Tyler. The homes are open to veterans who were not dishonorably discharged and their spouse, or unmarried surviving spouse. Gold Star parents are also eligible provided they meet the age and residency requirements above. Costs are based on income.

title: https://www.military.com/benefits/veteran-state-benefits/texas-state-veterans-benefits.html
content: Texas Veteran Financial Benefits Disabled Veterans Property Tax Exemption Total property tax exemption for 100% disabled veterans and their surviving spouses. Veterans with 10 - 90% VA disability can get a reduction of their home's' assessed value from $5,000 - $12,000 depending on disability percentage. Surviving spouses also qualify. Some counties offer homestead tax exemptions for veterans.

title: https://www.military.com/benefits/veteran-state-benefits/texas-state-veterans-benefits.html
content: Free Drivers License for Disabled Veterans Veterans with a service-connected disability of at least 60% and an honorable discharge can get a Texas driver license or ID card for free. Veteran Home Loans The Texas Veterans Land Board (VLB) offers generally below-market interest rates for home loans for Texas Veterans, lower rates for those who have a disability rating of 30% of more; home improvement and land loans.

title: https://www.military.com/benefits/veteran-state-benefits/texas-state-veterans-benefits.html
content: Texas is currently the only state to offer land loans – up to $150,000, with 5% down, and 30 year rates (depending on credit). Veterans Home Improvement Program (VHIP) The VLB offers home improvement loans up to $50,000 for a maximum 20 year payoff or a 10 year payoff for loans of $7,500 - $10,000. Veterans with a VA service-connected disability rating of 30% or greater qualify for a discounted interest rate. The loans may be used for alterations, repairs and improvements to the veteran's home.

title: https://www.military.com/benefits/veteran-state-benefits/texas-state-veterans-benefits.html
content: The improvements must substantially protect or improve the basic livability or utility of the property. Texas Veteran Education Benefits Hazlewood Act The Hazlewood Act is a State of Texas benefit that provides qualified veterans, spouses, and dependent children with an education benefit of up to 150 hours tuition free college at state schools. This does NOT include living expenses, books, or supply fees.

title: https://www.military.com/benefits/veteran-state-benefits/texas-state-veterans-benefits.html
content: The veteran must have: been a Texas resident when they entered the service and live there now. received an honorable discharge. served at least 181 days active duty. used up all federal VA education benefits. Legacy Act (Child) Veterans eligible for the Hazlewood Act can assign unused hours to a child under certain conditions. The child must: be a Texas resident. be the biological child, stepchild, adopted child, or claimed as a dependent in the current or previous tax year.

title: https://www.military.com/benefits/veteran-state-benefits/texas-state-veterans-benefits.html
content: be 25 years old or younger on the first day of the semester or term. meet GPA, academic progress and credit hour requirements. Only one child can use Hazlewood Legacy benefits at a time.

title: https://www.military.com/benefits/veteran-state-benefits/texas-state-veterans-benefits.html
content: Hazlewood Act for Spouse/Child Spouses and dependent children of eligible Active Duty, Reserve, and Texas National Guard who died in the line of duty, as a result of service-connected injury or illness, are missing in action, or who became totally disabled for purposes of employability as a result of a service-related injury or illness are entitled to each receive 50 credit hours tuition-free college.

title: https://www.military.com/benefits/veteran-state-benefits/texas-state-veterans-benefits.html
content: Like the normal Hazlewood act, the veteran must have been a Texas resident when they entered the service. A spouse must: have no federal VA education benefits. be a Texas resident. meet GPA, academic progress and credit hour requirements. A child must: have no federal VA education benefits. be a Texas resident. meet GPA, academic progress and credit hour requirements. This requirement does not apply to the child of a MIA, KIA, or service connected deceased Veteran.

title: https://www.military.com/benefits/veteran-state-benefits/texas-state-veterans-benefits.html
content: Texas Veteran Employment Benefits Veterans Preference Wartime veterans have preference in employment with state agencies or offices, as do widows and children of those killed on active duty.  State agencies must practice veterans' preference until they have reached 40% veteran employment.

title: https://www.military.com/benefits/veteran-state-benefits/texas-state-veterans-benefits.html
content: Military Time Credit Towards State Retirement Non-retired veterans who are state employees can claim their active duty military time toward retirement by making a payment equal to the monthly contribution an employee would make times the number of months active duty. The maximum anyone can buy is 60 months. Veteran Entrepreneur Program The Veteran Entrepreneur Program provides veteran entrepreneurs and veteran small businesses the tools they need to start or grow their businesses.

title: https://www.military.com/benefits/veteran-state-benefits/texas-state-veterans-benefits.html
content: The program provides consultation with business plans, financing, marketing and more. Texas Veteran Recreation Benefits Disabled Veterans Hunting & Fishing License Disabled veterans with a 50% or greater disability or who are suffered the loss of use of a foot or leg as a result of service can get a free "Super Combo" Hunting and All-Water Fishing Package. You do not have to be a Texas resident to qualify.

title: https://www.military.com/benefits/veteran-state-benefits/texas-state-veterans-benefits.html
content: Active Duty Hunting & Fishing License The "Super Combo" Hunting and All-Water Fishing Package is available at no cost to TX residents on active duty. Military members (and their dependents) on active duty anywhere are entitled to purchase a license at the resident rate. Disabled Veterans State Park Pass Any veteran with a 60% or greater disability or a service-connected loss of lower extremity is eligible for free admission to Texas state parks. You do not have to be a Texas resident to qualify.

title: https://www.military.com/benefits/veteran-state-benefits/texas-state-veterans-benefits.html
content: Texas Veterans Cemeteries Texas has four state veterans cemeteries in Abilene, Corpus Christi, Killeen, and Mission. All Texas veterans their spouses and dependent children are eligible for burial. There is no charge for burial of the veteran or their family. Visit the Texas Veterans Commission website for more information on any of these programs. Stay on Top of Your Veteran Benefits Military benefits are always changing.
